sys.h

00032 #ifndef __LWIP_SYS_H__
00033 #define __LWIP_SYS_H__
00034 
00035 #include "arch/cc.h"
00036 
00037 #include "lwip/opt.h"
00038 
00039 
00040 #if NO_SYS
00041 
00042 /* For a totally minimal and standalone system, we provide null
00043    definitions of the sys_ functions. */
00044 typedef u8_t sys_sem_t;
00045 typedef u8_t sys_mbox_t;
00046 struct sys_timeout {u8_t dummy;};
00047 
00048 #define sys_init()
00049 #define sys_timeout(m,h,a)
00050 #define sys_untimeout(m,a)
00051 #define sys_sem_new(c) c
00052 #define sys_sem_signal(s)
00053 #define sys_sem_wait(s)
00054 #define sys_sem_free(s)
00055 #define sys_mbox_new() 0
00056 #define sys_mbox_fetch(m,d)
00057 #define sys_mbox_post(m,d)
00058 #define sys_mbox_free(m)
00059 
00060 #define sys_thread_new(t,a,p)
00061 
00062 #else /* NO_SYS */
00063 
00064 #include "arch/sys_arch.h"
00065 
00067 #define SYS_ARCH_TIMEOUT 0xffffffff
00068 
00069 typedef void (* sys_timeout_handler)(void *arg);
00070 
00071 struct sys_timeout {
00072   struct sys_timeout *next;
00073   u32_t time;
00074   sys_timeout_handler h;
00075   void *arg;
00076 };
00077 
00078 struct sys_timeouts {
00079   struct sys_timeout *next;
00080 };
00081 
00082 /* sys_init() must be called before anthing else. */
00083 void sys_init(void);
00084 
00085 /*
00086  * sys_timeout():
00087  *
00088  * Schedule a timeout a specified amount of milliseconds in the
00089  * future. When the timeout occurs, the specified timeout handler will
00090  * be called. The handler will be passed the "arg" argument when
00091  * called.
00092  *
00093  */
00094 void sys_timeout(u32_t msecs, sys_timeout_handler h, void *arg);
00095 void sys_untimeout(sys_timeout_handler h, void *arg);
00096 struct sys_timeouts *sys_arch_timeouts(void);
00097 
00098 /* Semaphore functions. */
00099 sys_sem_t sys_sem_new(u8_t count);
00100 void sys_sem_signal(sys_sem_t sem);
00101 u32_t sys_arch_sem_wait(sys_sem_t sem, u32_t timeout);
00102 void sys_sem_free(sys_sem_t sem);
00103 void sys_sem_wait(sys_sem_t sem);
00104 int sys_sem_wait_timeout(sys_sem_t sem, u32_t timeout);
00105 
00106 /* Time functions. */
00107 #ifndef sys_msleep
00108 void sys_msleep(u32_t ms); /* only has a (close to) 1 jiffy resolution. */
00109 #endif
00110 #ifndef sys_jiffies
00111 u32_t sys_jiffies(void); /* since power up. */
00112 #endif
00113 
00114 /* Mailbox functions. */
00115 sys_mbox_t sys_mbox_new(void);
00116 void sys_mbox_post(sys_mbox_t mbox, void *msg);
00117 u32_t sys_arch_mbox_fetch(sys_mbox_t mbox, void **msg, u32_t timeout);
00118 void sys_mbox_free(sys_mbox_t mbox);
00119 void sys_mbox_fetch(sys_mbox_t mbox, void **msg);
00120 
00121 
00122 /* Thread functions. */
00123 sys_thread_t sys_thread_new(void (* thread)(void *arg), void *arg, int prio);
00124 
00125 /* The following functions are used only in Unix code, and
00126    can be omitted when porting the stack. */
00127 /* Returns the current time in microseconds. */
00128 unsigned long sys_now(void);
00129 
00130 #endif /* NO_SYS */
00131 
00132 /* Critical Region Protection */
00133 /* These functions must be implemented in the sys_arch.c file.
00134    In some implementations they can provide a more light-weight protection
00135    mechanism than using semaphores. Otherwise semaphores can be used for
00136    implementation */
00137 #ifndef SYS_ARCH_PROTECT
00138 
00143 #if SYS_LIGHTWEIGHT_PROT
00144 
00150 #define SYS_ARCH_DECL_PROTECT(lev) sys_prot_t lev
00151 
00160 #define SYS_ARCH_PROTECT(lev) lev = sys_arch_protect()
00161 
00169 #define SYS_ARCH_UNPROTECT(lev) sys_arch_unprotect(lev)
00170 sys_prot_t sys_arch_protect(void);
00171 void sys_arch_unprotect(sys_prot_t pval);
00172 
00173 #else
00174 
00175 #define SYS_ARCH_DECL_PROTECT(lev)
00176 #define SYS_ARCH_PROTECT(lev)
00177 #define SYS_ARCH_UNPROTECT(lev)
00178 
00179 #endif /* SYS_LIGHTWEIGHT_PROT */
00180 
00181 #endif /* SYS_ARCH_PROTECT */
00182 
00183 #endif /* __LWIP_SYS_H__ */
